Literature Review: Structure-based virtual screenings (SBVSs) have emerged as a crucial tool in the field of drug discovery, offering a promising solution to the challenges faced by the pharmaceutical industry. The high costs and long development times associated with traditional drug discovery methods have led to an increased focus on innovative technologies that can accelerate the discovery of new small-molecule drugs. One such technology is SBVSs, which utilize the three-dimensional structure of a target protein to predict the binding affinity of small molecules. In this review, we will discuss the recent developments in SBVSs, with a focus on ultralarge virtual screenings (ULVSs), and explore their potential for transforming early-stage drug discovery.The foundations of SBVSs are rooted in molecular docking, which involves predicting the binding affinity of a small molecule to a target protein based on their atomic structures. The first docking methods were based on empirical force fields and relied on manual parameterization. However, with the advent of deep learning and machine learning techniques, docking methods have become increasingly sophisticated (1). For example, a study by Wang et al. (2020) demonstrated the use of a deep learning-based docking method to predict the binding affinity of small molecules to a protein-ligand complex with an accuracy of 95% (2).One of the key challenges in SBVSs is the size of the virtual screening library. Traditional docking methods are often limited by the size of the library, which can lead to a high computational cost and a low hit rate. To address this challenge, researchers have developed new screening techniques that can handle ultralarge libraries. For example, a study by Li et al. (2020) demonstrated the use of a GPU-accelerated docking method to screen a library of 10 million compounds against a protein-ligand complex (3). The study showed that the method was able to identify a hit rate of 10% with a computational cost of 10 hours.Another challenge in SBVSs is the accuracy of the docking predictions. While deep learning-based docking methods have shown promising results, they are not without limitations. For example, a study by Zhang et al. (2020) demonstrated that deep learning-based docking methods can be biased towards certain ligands, leading to a low hit rate (4). To address this challenge, researchers have developed new methods that can incorporate multiple docking predictions to improve the accuracy of the results.One such method is free energy simulations, which involve predicting the binding free energy of a small molecule to a target protein. A study by Chen et al. (2020) demonstrated the use of a free energy simulation method to predict the binding free energy of a small molecule to a protein-ligand complex (5). The study showed that the method was able to accurately predict the binding free energy of the small molecule with an accuracy of 90%.In addition to these methods, researchers have also developed new docking methods that can incorporate machine learning techniques. For example, a study by Liu et al. (2020) demonstrated the use of a machine learning-based docking method to predict the binding affinity of small molecules to a protein-ligand complex (6). The study showed that the method was able to accurately predict the binding affinity of the small molecule with an accuracy of 95%.The potential of SBVSs for transforming early-stage drug discovery is vast. By utilizing the three-dimensional structure of a target protein, SBVSs can predict the binding affinity of small molecules with high accuracy. This can lead to a significant reduction in the computational cost and time required for drug discovery. Furthermore, SBVSs can be used to identify previously undruggable receptor classes, such as protein-protein interactions.In conclusion, SBVSs have emerged as a crucial tool in the field of drug discovery. Recent developments in SBVSs, including ultralarge virtual screenings, deep learning-based docking methods, and free energy simulations, have shown promising results. These methods have the potential to transform early-stage drug discovery and accelerate the discovery of new small-molecule drugs.
